top_comment.text:
Thank you for these nice pictures of Kahlgrundbahn.
Most of the operational steam locomotives in Germany are "Reko" versions 
rebuilt by the Deutsche Reichsbahn in the east. Deutsche Bundesbahn in the 
west retired them around 1970, with some examples operating to the 
mid-1970s, whereas the DR kept considerable numbers right until 
reunification, which gave the museum railways something to choose from - 
even though such a "Reko-50" never operated on the Kahlgrundbahn in earlier 
eras.
The rolling stock: one "Donnerbüchse" (red, pre-war 2-axle coach for branch 
lines), one freight wagon used for baggage (bicycles?) and the rest are 
"Umbauwagen" built by DB in the 1950s using components of damaged pre-war 
types that they had plentiful at that time.

I think they only operate the museum train in summer and on some weekends 
in december. It takes a lot of work to operate a steam locomotive: Heat it 
up for hours, make sure everything is well oiled, and afterwards, clean out 
all the ashes ...﻿

comments.text:
Some tracks in Germany are tourist attractions because of their steam 
trains- they are all narrow gauge and the locos are all classified as 99 - 
no matter who built them and how they are designed. The best known ones are 
all in the former East, that is the "Harzer Querbahn" in the Harz Mountains 
near Goslar or Quedlinburg, the "Molly" between the town of Bad Doberan and 
Bad Kühlungsborn at the Baltic and the "Rasender Roland" on the island of 
Rügen. Then there are trains in the "Erzgebirge" the "ore-mountains"- a 
very picturesque landscape that you have to go through on your way from 
Dresden to Prague. All these trains run on schedule.
The German state railway Deutsche Bahn sometimes takes some of their 
preserved steam locos out of their museum, steams them up and lets them 
pull trains on schedule as well - those are the "Plandampf" events that 
steam enthusiasts love so much, as it gives them the feeling of doing the 
"real thing".
Besides that there is a great number of clubs and societies like the steam 
friends in Hanau who are happy to have the means to keep steam locos in 
good shape, have the expensive boiler and other safety tests done and  have 
access to track that still allows steam traction ( fire risk from hot 
ashes!!!).
One thing that is a great blessing for the survival of steam locos in 
working order is the maintenance shop in Sachsen-Meiningen. Once part of 
East Germany's railway it is now a private enterprise that is the last real 
steam loco maintenance shop in Europe that can do all necessary jobs, from 
drilling cylinders, making complete boilers, turning 7 ft drivewheels...

captions.text:
Last weekend we decided to take a trip
to the Schöllkrippen Christmas Market.
Since Schöllkrippen is a terminus,

a steam locomotive has to perform
a complicated sequence of moves

to get to the other end of the train
for the trip back.
This particular engine was made in 1942.

After the war, it was used
for many decades in East Germany,
where it was also given a major refit.

Now, it is in the hands of a society
of train enthusiasts in Hanau.

The Christmas Market in Schöllkrippen
is very small;
but then, Schöllkrippen is very small.

But just enough for a little diversion,
and something to eat,
such as a wild boar sausage.
There’s a larger market in Aschaffenburg;

not surprising, since
Aschaffenburg is a larger city.

In the Middle Ages, when there were
no supermarkets you could just go to
whenever you needed something,

a winter market was the way
people would stock up on essentials,
so they had something to eat in the cold season.

Now, instead of essentials, they sell
decorations, trinkets and treats,
most importantly, of course, Glühwein:

the famous mulled wine
served in a special commemorative cup.

The Christmas Market is a concept which Germany
has recently begun exporting;
and quite successfully, according to the reports.

title: Of steam trains and mulled wine
